DataElement.preferredName: Tobacco Use Change Low Nicotine Cigarette History Assessment Text
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Use of tobacco in any form i.e. smoking, chewing or sniffing._The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character._A minimum level or position or degree; less than normal in degree, intensity or amount._A plant alkaloid, found in the tobacco plant, and addictive central nervous system (CNS) stimulant that causes either ganglionic stimulation in low doses or ganglionic blockage in high doses. Nicotine acts as an agonist at the nicotinic cholinergic receptors in the autonomic ganglia, at neuromuscular junctions, and in the adrenal medulla and the brain. Nicotine's CNS-stimulating activities may be mediated through the release of several neurotransmitters, including acetylcholine, beta-endorphin, dopamine, norepinephrine, serotonin, and ACTH. As a result, peripheral vasoconstriction, tachycardia, and elevated blood pressure may be observed with nicotine intake. This agent may also stimulate the chemoreceptor trigger zone, thereby inducing nausea and vomiting._Finely cut tobacco encased in a wrapper of thin paper and rolled for smoking._The aggregate of past events; the continuum of events occurring in succession leading from the past to the present; a record or narrative description of past events._a free text field to specify information on the evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Use of tobacco in any form i.e. smoking, chewing or sniffing.

Concepts.definition: Use of tobacco in any form, e.g., smoking, chewing or sniffing.

Property.preferredDefinition: The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.:A minimum level or position or degree; less than normal in degree, intensity or amount.:A plant alkaloid, found in the tobacco plant, and addictive central nervous system (CNS) stimulant that causes either ganglionic stimulation in low doses or ganglionic blockage in high doses. Nicotine acts as an agonist at the nicotinic cholinergic receptors in the autonomic ganglia, at neuromuscular junctions, and in the adrenal medulla and the brain. Concepts.definition: The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.
A minimum level or position or degree; less than normal in degree, intensity or amount.

A plant alkaloid, found in the tobacco plant, and addictive central nervous system (CNS) stimulant that causes either ganglionic stimulation in low doses or ganglionic blockage in high doses. Nicotine acts as an agonist at the nicotinic cholinergic receptors in the autonomic ganglia, at neuromuscular junctions, and in the adrenal medulla and the brain. Nicotine's CNS-stimulating activities may be mediated through the release of several neurotransmitters, including acetylcholine, beta-endorphin, dopamine, norepinephrine, serotonin, and ACTH. As a result, peripheral vasoconstriction, tachycardia, and elevated blood pressure may be observed with nicotine intake. This agent may also stimulate the chemoreceptor trigger zone, thereby inducing nausea and vomiting.
Finely cut tobacco encased in a wrapper of thin paper and rolled for smoking.
The aggregate of past events; the continuum of events occurring in succession leading from the past to the present; a record or narrative description of past events.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.
